posts.name: joemost
posts.cooked:
Is there a preferred method for creating a turn in place trajectory?

looking at the examples calling trajectory generator, they wall want to drive some sort of curve

posts.name: NewtonCrosby
posts.cooked:
I’m trying to wrap my brain around the terminology of  trajectory in this case.

We’ve used MotionMagic in the CTRE motor controllers to have a rotational turn in place using a trapezoidal motion profile, we’ve also just used standard PID controllers to turn to a given angle.

I’m not understanding whether either of those would qualify as a turn-in-place trajectory.

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked:
There’s currently no support in WPILib for generating instances of the Trajectory class that perform turn-in-place functions.  We’ve discussed it a few times, and it’s on the radar for potential future additions.

For now, you can generate such a Trajectory manually with a TrapezoidProfile , or else use a ProfiledPIDController (or even a raw PIDController ).

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked:
Look at the Trajectory class and the TrapezoidProfile class.

Can you imagine how you might be able to make an instance of TrapezoidProfile that represents a turn from one heading to another?

Can you see how you could turn such an instance of TrapezoidProfile into an instance of Trajectory that represents the same?  (hint: what needs to happen to convert a TrapezoidProfile.State into a Trajectory.State ?)

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked: Try taking the last Trajectory.State from the previous trajectory, and using that as a “base” to create a sequence of states that represents the turn.

posts.name: Christopher149

Ours from last year wasn’t a turn in place trajectory, but a separate command we wrote for turning in place.

TurnToAngleCommand.java RobotContainer.java , see getFiveBallTrenchRunCommand()

posts.name: Wolly :)
posts.cooked: Is there a reason you need to use a trajectory? I think you could do a simple PID on gyro angle, or a ProfiledPID . Its been a while since I’ve touched a robot so I don’t have experience with using the Trajectories or anything like that. I’d imagine if you are driving trajectories before and/or after turning in place, you could create them as separate commands and run them sequentially.

link_counts.title: Combining Motion Profiling and PID Control with ProfiledPIDController — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked:
So, a Trajectory.State contains the following information:

time

velocity

acceleration

pose

curvature

A TrapezoidProfile.State contains the following information:

time (implicit, passed into the sample function)

position

velocity

You need to take your starting Trajectory.State , and use the rotational positions and velocities from the TrapezoidProfile.State s to generate a sequence of of Trajectory.State s that represent the turn.  The conversion might look something like (pseudocode):

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!

posts.custom_user_title: Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!

posts.name: joemost
posts.cooked:
OH! Okay. This is starting to make a little more sense!

So I guess the missing piece of this for me is somehow you have a TrapezoidProfile of a turn? Somehow generating one from poses?

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked: Yep.  Take the heading of your start pose, use that as your start position.  Make the profile range to the heading of your end pose.
